creator: Ansamb

content:
Unfortunately, there is no easy way; getting rid of spam can require a strong focus initially, and then periodic maintenance tasks. Here are my thoughts, as I am not aware of any official article on spam:

Use the Thunderbird Junk filter. This is a powerful feature, but requires ongoing training. That is, it is not very helpful if you just mark junk. You need to also routinely mark what is NOT junk. This helps Thunderbird 'learn' your email. There is an excellent article on this at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

There are several third-party tools that may also help. - Mailwasher is free for one account. I have used for years and it works very well - there is also spampal and spamcom that are both free to use - your email provider may have spam filtering tools that are also available - if your email is self-hosted, then mxguarddog is also free and powerful.

Some combination of all this may reduce your spam. Good luck.
creator: davidsk

content:
Dear All I found the solution myself, problem is Windows Defender. I put the Thunderbird maps as an exception. After that the Thunderbird worked like before, but why Windows Defender sees Thunderbird as a virus I don't know.

So don't reinstall, but make an exception.
creator: Henk.Hoenderop

content: I'm having similar issues and I use Windows defender, how do I create this exception?
creator: bjcanfer

content:
Hi Brian

Go to the windows settings, look for privacy and protection, select windows security select the first item with the protecting shield, select the second item settings for virus and threat the last item will be exceptions, there you place by selecting:

C:\program files\mozilla thunderbird\thunderbird.exe (file) C:\user\ ... \appdata\local\thunderbird (map) C:\user\ ... \appdata\roaming\thunderbird (map) "C:\program files\mozilla thunderbird\thunderbird.exe" (proces)

This did the trick for me, hope it will for you too.
creator: Henk.Hoenderop

content: To install on laptop, you can export the profile with Tools>export from desktop, install Thunderbird on laptop and then use tools>import to install the profile. At this time, there is no profile import capability for smartphones. For consistent access, use IMAP for accounts.

content:
Ok, no easy answer. If account was IMAP (ask stepfather), the data may all still be on server. If a POP account, read this article carefully: http://kb.mozillazine.org/Recovering_deleted_mail_accounts

Do not make any changes without first verifying what is there. Do NOT delete everything and reinstall thunderbird, hoping that will give rebirth; that could eliminate what you're seeking. Go slowly.
creator: davidsk

content: Filters are stored in msgFilterRules.dat in each account subfolder of Mail or ImapMail in the profile. The file can be copied between accounts on the same or different computers, and I expect this remains true between different operating systems, as long as OS-dependent changes are made if necessary, e.g. file or folder paths.
creator: sfhowes
